data.text: Pinion Gearbox with Gates Belt Drive for Long-Distance Bike Touring?

Trying to gather anecdotal evidence for or against setting up a build with the 18 gear Pinion Gearbox and Gates belt drive. Bike will be seeing a lot of snow, possible sand, and tons of elevation change. Any advice for or against the gearbox with belt drive would be appreciated. Thank you

I run a 12 speed Pinion on my Idworx, hardly any negatives! Some weight perhaps, and be aware of the extra tension stress it puts on the rear hub, so that one needs to be solid (DT Swiss is good). Not sure you’ll need the 18 speed, maybe if it’s more of a road bike configuration instead of mountainbike.
data.author: Vincent Klein Breteler

data.text: Do you perceive much drivetrain friction loss compared to a chain/derailleur setup? This is probably my biggest concern - less so for bikepacking, but more so if I wanted to use it for endurance races
data.author: Brian Turk

data.text: don’t worry about it. Some folks claim there should be less friction even with a belt drive.
data.author: Vincent Klein Breteler

data.text: *Following* Seems to me that the 18sp would be preferable for well-loaded ADV-touring in mountains but I keep hearing "12sp is fine".. so what's the 18sp for then?..

data.text: I have done a bit of research on this as I am dreaming of a Pinion bike as well. 18 speed has tighter gear ratios, so probably better for road touring where that is nice to have. However, the lighter weight version is not available in 18 - only 12. The overall gear range is the same for 12 and 18 - just different spacing
data.author: Brian Turk

data.text: Um, nope - C.12 & P.12 are 600%, P.18 is 636%.. To me, the advantage of closer gears means the ability to be at your ideal cadence whatever the gradient of the road, which is trickier to do the more loaded you are..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: yup - you are correct. Seems the low end is the same though and that is what I would be more concerned about. The 18 has a bigger top end, which, yeah - road

data.text: so what's the difference between a c12 and p12? I've not heard of the p12 before.
data.author: Justin Sher

data.text: I wanted the answer to this once and for all so I asked Pinion themselves. This was their reply: "The typical application of the P1.18 gearbox is clearly in the travel bike / touring area. The gearbox versions with 12 gears, as P1.12 & C1.12 can be found more in the mountain bike area"
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Limited amount of frames to choose from if using Pinion. Using a Rohloff (I do) has its downsides too, but can be used with numerous frames. Something to consider.
data.author: Ryan Elvis Dunham

data.text: Pinions and Gates combos are the bomb for bikepacking and tough conditions. They are, by far, the best investment I’ve made in 37+ years of riding. I have both a p1.18 and a c1.12. Honestly, I prefer the c1.12. In the rolling terrain that I ride, I find that the 18 requires too much shifting. The additional drag (if it actually exists in the real world) is inconsequential. I’m over 50 and have no problems keeping up with the younger crowds.
data.author: Kevin Wirtanen

data.text: I run a 12 speed pinion. IMO it’s the perfect setup for touring/bikepacking. I have more gear range than I usually need. I do notice getting started from a stop takes a little more muscle than with standard drivetrain, but once I’m going, there is no difference or extra resistance. I don’t do any racing, but I think the extra initial resistance could be a hindrance there, depending on how competitive you are. If you ride drop bars you have to get creative with the shifter. I tried all available options (Cinq, Co-motions, and stock pinion shifter) and landed with the stock shifter mounted to a simple accessory mount extender. If you run flat bars then no problem. The shifting takes some getting used to because you cannot shift into an easier gear while pedaling at all. It’s a little more extreme than just backing off the pedals a bit like you do with a standard derailleur. This is a big turn off for a lot of people. It was tricky for me at first, but once I got used to it and got my timing down, I loved the ability to shift to any gear. Think of releasing pressure off the pedals like putting in the clutch of a car, you can then put it in any gear you want. You can also switch gears when you are stopped, which has been a convenience I didn’t realize I was missing. The gearbox itself is pretty bombproof. Completely sealed and only requires annual oil changes, which are so easy. If you pair it with a gates belt drive you end up with a nearly maintenance free system. Occasionally I rinse off the belt with some water because it gets squeaky in dusty conditions, but that doesn’t affect the performance.
data.author: Megan Rose

data.text: I have a custom Co-Motion steel frame with the P1.18 and gates belt. As expected with a custom build, the fit is perfect and it rides really, really nice. Bit on the heavy side (32lbs unloaded). Make sure you calculate what you want your end gear ratio to be. IIRC, The Pinion has a 0.55 internal granny gear, but you adjust that with the sizes of the sprockets on the outside. Mine came with a 39T front and 34T in back, which was a bit harder than I wanted, so I switched the front to a 32T (had to replace the belt too) and now it feels good to me climbing. I lost some speed at the top end, but I prefer being able to spin easy up harder hills while loaded…
data.author: Mike Enfield

data.text:
Also, get a tool to check the belt tension, especially if you need to remove the rear wheel for any reason. There is an app that measures frequency when you strum the belt, but I always get wildly differing values, so I prefer the tension tool. This is the one I use. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000MUTAGS?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share
Gates 91107 Krikit V-Belt Tension Gauge, Black
amazon.com
data.author: Mike Enfield

data.text:
One more thing… the belt may pop off in heavy mud (it’s happened to me). Never force it back on. Always remove the wheel and reset it that way. Forcing it will damage the belt. Duzer has a good video explaining why. https://youtu.be/JO8466-4NSs
Why Did my Gates Carbon Belt Fail? +Tips to Prevent a Future Break
youtube.com
data.author: Mike Enfield

data.text: I have a priority 600x, absolutely love it. My wife just got a regular chain/gear system and it's like night and day. I have a 12 gear, though I'm not super experienced in bikepacking, but I've ridden several hundred miles and up steep hills and never needed more gears. I absolutely love the lack of maintenance, the belt itself is awesome, the gearbox is awesome. I don't really have any cons. Maybe the weight, but I'm not obsessed with being super lightweight. Love love love the pinion system. Shifting from a standstill, smooth shifting, just everything about it. Get it.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Thank you all for the comments. I appreciate it all. The gearbox is going to be put on my custom ti frame.
data.author: Cody Lee

data.text: Just ridden from Melbourne to Cape York(6000km) on a Viral Bike, Derive with the C12 and Gates belt. The best thing for me was the no maintenance at the end of each day. It was a very wet summer here in Oz and I just set up my tent and got out of the rain asap. Only down side is the grip shift, it can be hard to turn with wet hands, I ride with glove mainly so not a big issue.
data.author: Roger Norton

data.text: I would go with a gearbox if I had a do-over
